analyzed: ārya anityatā sūtram
translated: The Noble Sutra on Impermanence

analyzed: om namaḥ sarvajñāya
translated: Om, homage to the Omniscient One

original: evaṃ mayā śrutamekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyāṃ viharati sma jetavane 'nāthapiṇḍadasyārāme mahatā bhikṣusaṃghena sārddhaṃ trayodaśabhirbhikṣuśataiḥ
analyzed: evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyām viharati sma jetavane nāthapiṇḍadasya ārāme mahatā bhikṣu saṃghena sārddham trayodaśabhiḥ bhikṣu śataiḥ
translated: Thus have I heard. At one time, the Blessed One was dwelling in Shravasti, in the Jeta Grove, in the garden of Anathapindada, together with a great assembly of thirteen hundred and fifty monks.

analyzed: tatra khalu bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayate sma
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the monks:

original: anityā bhikṣavaḥ sarvasaṃskārā adhruvā anāsvāsikā vipariṇāmadharmāṇaḥ /
analyzed: anityāḥ bhikṣavaḥ sarva saṃskārāḥ adhruvāḥ anāsvāsikāḥ vipariṇāma dharmāṇaḥ
translated: Monks, all conditioned things are impermanent, unstable, unreliable, subject to change.

original: yadyāvat bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyo 'laṃ nirvartitumalaṃ viraktamalaṃ vimoktum /
analyzed: yat yāvat bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ lam nirvartitum alam viraktam alam vimoktum
translated: Monks, it is enough to feel revulsion towards all conditioned things, enough to feel detached, enough to be liberated from them.

original: sarveṣāṃ sattvānāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāṃ prāṇināṃ āmaraṇānta hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇam /
analyzed: sarveṣām sattvānām sarveṣām bhūtānām sarveṣām prāṇinām āmaraṇānta hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: For all beings, all creatures, all living beings, life ends in death, there is no escape from it. For the born there is no escape from death.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo gṛhapatayo mahāśālakulā brāhmaṇa mahāśālakulākṣatriya mahāśālakulā
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ gṛhapatayaḥ mahā śāla kulāḥ brāhmaṇa mahā śāla kula a kṣatriya mahā śāla kulā
translated: Monks, those householders from great merchant families, great brahmin families, and great ruling class families,

analyzed: āśām mahādhanaḥ mahā bhogāḥ prabhūta maṇi māṇikya muktā vaidurya śaṃkha śilā pravāla jātarūpa rajata vikaraṇāḥ
translated: who are very wealthy, with great riches and property, with abundant jewels, pearls, lapis lazuli, conch shells, quartz, coral, gold, silver, and other valuables,

analyzed: prabhūta dhana dhānya koṣa koṣṭhāgāra sannicayāḥ prabhūta dāsī dāsa karmakara prabhūta mitra amātya jñāti sālohitāḥ teṣām api
translated: They have abundant wealth, grain, treasuries, and storehouses. They have abundant female and male servants, workers, and personnel. They have abundant friends, ministers, relatives, and kinsmen. For them too

analyzed: maraṇa antam jīvita maraṇam paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: life ends in death. It ends in death, there is no life without death.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāśca murddhābhiṣiktā jānapadai śvaryasthāmavīryamanuprāptā mahāntaṃ pṛthvīmaṇḍalamabhinirjityā vasanti /
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ca murddhābhiṣiktāḥ jānapadaiḥ śvarya sthāma vīryam anuprāptāḥ mahāntam pṛthvī maṇḍalam abhinirjitya ā vasanti
translated: Those who are kings, anointed kṣatriyas, who have attained sovereignty, power, and valor in the country, and who live after conquering a great circle of the earth,

original: teṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: for them too life ends in death. It ends in death, there is no life without death.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ ṛṣayo vānaprasthāḥ pramukta phalāhārāḥ prabhūktaphala bhojinaḥ pramukta phalena yāpanti teṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvita maraṇaparyavasānaṃ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ ṛṣayaḥ vānaprasthāḥ pramukta phala āhārāḥ prabhūktaphala bhojinaḥ pramukta phalena yāpanti teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam
translated: Those who are sages, forest-dwellers, who eat freely given fruits, who eat freely given food, and who subsist on freely given fruits, for them too life ends in death. It ends in death,

analyzed: na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: there is no life without death.

analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ kāmāvacāra devāḥ cāturmahārājikā devāḥ trayāḥ triśān devāḥ nāmāḥ tuṣitāḥ devāḥ nirmāṇaratayaḥ devāḥ
translated: Those who are gods dwelling in the desire realm, the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the Yāma gods, the Tuṣita gods, the Nirmāṇarati gods,🔽the Brahmakāyika gods, the Brahmapurohita gods, the Mahābrahma gods, the Parīttābha gods, the Apramāṇābha gods, the Ābhāsvara gods, the Parīttaśubha gods, the Apramāṇaśubha gods, the Śubhakṛtsna gods, the Bṛhatphala gods, the Asaṃjñisattva gods, the Avṛha gods, the Atapa gods, the Sudarśana gods, the Akaniṣṭha gods, the gods of the sphere of infinite space, the gods of the sphere of infinite consciousness, the gods of the sphere of nothingness, the gods of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: paranirmitavaśavartinodevāsteṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇa paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ devāḥ teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: The gods who control the enjoyments created by others, their life also ends in death. Death is the end. There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo rūpiṇo devāḥ prathamadhyānalābhino brahmakāyikā brahmapurohitā mahābrahmāṇaḥ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ rūpiṇaḥ devāḥ prathama dhyāna lābhinaḥ brahmakāyikāḥ brahmapurohitāḥ mahābrahmāṇaḥ
translated: Monks, those gods who are embodied, who attain the first dhyāna, the Brahmakāyika, Brahmapurohita, Mahābrahmā gods,

original: dvitīya dhyānalābhina parītābhā apramāṇābhā ābhāśvarā stṛtīyadhyāna lābhinaḥparītaśubhā
analyzed: dvitīya dhyāna lābhinaḥ apramāṇa ābhā tṛtīya dhyāna lābhinaḥ
translated: who attain the second dhyāna, the Parīttābha, Apramāṇābha, Ābhāsvara gods, who attain the third dhyāna, the Parīttaśubha,

original: apramāṇaśubhā śubhakṛtsnā caturthadhyāna lābhinonabhrakā puṇyaprasavā bṛhatphalā
analyzed: apramāṇaśubhā śubhakṛtsnā puṇyaprasavā bṛhatphalā
translated: Apramāṇaśubha, Śubhakṛtsna gods, who attain the fourth dhyāna, the Anabhraka, Puṇyaprasava, Bṛhatphala,

original: avṛhā atapā sudṛśāḥ sudarśanā akaniṣṭhāścadevāsteṣāmapi maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaṃ🔽paryavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: avṛhāḥ atapāḥ sudṛśāḥ sudarśanāḥ akaniṣṭhāḥ ca devāḥ teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇam  paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: Avrha, Atapa, Sudṛśa, Sudarśana, Akaniṣṭha gods, their life also ends in death. Death is the end. There is no immortality for one who is born.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ ārūpiṇodevā ākāśānantaāyatanopagā vijñānantyāyatanopagā ākiṃcanyāyatanopagā🔽naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanopagāśca devāsteṣāmapi maraṇāntahi jīvita maraṇaṃ paryavasāna
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ ārūpiṇaḥ devāḥ ākāśa ananta āyatana upagāḥ vijñā anantya āyatana upagāḥ ākiṃcanya āyatana upagāḥ  na eva saṃjñā na asaṃjñā āyatana upagāḥ ca devāḥ teṣām api maraṇam
translated: Monks, those gods who are formless, who have gone to the sphere of infinite space, who have gone to the sphere of infinite consciousness, who have gone to the sphere of nothingness,

analyzed: na asti jātasya amaraṇa
translated: who have gone to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, their life also ends in death. Death is the end. There is no immortality for one who is born.

analyzed: traidhātukam idam
translated: This is the three realms.

original: yepi te bhikṣavo 'rhantaḥ kṣīṇāsravā kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛtakaraṇīyā apahṛtabhārā anuprāptatvākāthā
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ rhantaḥ kṣīṇa āsravāḥ kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛta karaṇīyāḥ apahṛta bhārāḥ
translated: Those monks who are arhats, whose defilements are exhausted, who have done what had to be done, who have accomplished what had to be done, who have cast off the burden, who have attained their own goal,

analyzed: parikṣīṇa bhava saṃyojanaḥ samyagājñāsu vimukta cittāḥ sarva cetaḥ vaśi parama pāramitā prāptāḥ teṣām api
translated: who have exhausted the fetters of existence, whose minds are well liberated by right knowledge, who have attained the highest perfection of mastery over all mental states, even for them

analyzed: kāya nikṣepaṇa dharmāḥ
translated: this body has the nature of being cast aside.

original: yepi te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhā khaḍga viṣāṇakalpā ekamātmāna damayanti ekamātmāna śamayati ekamātmātmānaṃparinirvāyanti teṣāmapi 'yaṃkāyonikṣepaṇadharmaḥ🔽yepi te bhikṣavastathāgatā arhantaḥ samyak saṃbuddhādaśavalavalinaḥudārārṣamāḥsamyak siṃhanādanādineścaturvaiśāradyadharmārohaṇa vaiśāradyaṃ
analyzed: ye api te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhā khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpāḥ ekam ātmāna damayanti ekam ātmāna śamayati ekam ātma ātmānam parinirvāyanti teṣām api yaṃkāyaḥ nikṣepaṇa dharmaḥ  ye api te bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyak saṃbuddhāḥ daśa vala valinaḥ udāra ārṣamāḥ samyak
translated: Those monks who are pratyekabuddhas, who are like rhinoceroses, who tame themselves alone, who pacify themselves alone, who attain parinirvāṇa alone, even for them🔽this body has the nature of being cast aside.

analyzed: sarva dharma deśanā vaiśāradyam nirvāṇa mārga avatāraṇa vaiśāradyam āśrava jñāna prahāṇa avaiśāradyam
translated: Those monks who are tathāgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones, who roar the roar of a fearless lion with their ten powers, their four forms of fearlessness, their four forms of unobstructed knowledge, their eighteen distinctive qualities of a buddha, their thirty-two major marks of a great being, and their eighty minor marks,

analyzed: viśada adṛḍha nārāyaṇa saṃhata kāyāḥ teṣām api dharmaḥ
translated: who have the clear and firm body of Nārāyaṇa, even for them this body has the nature of being cast aside.

original: tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhakārakṛtāni bhāṇḍāniśrāmānivāpakvāni va bhedanaparyantāni
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhakāra kṛtāni bhāṇḍa a niśrāmān iva apakvāni bhedana paryantāni
translated: Just as, monks, all the vessels made by a potter, whether baked or unbaked,

original: bhedana paryavasānānyevameva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣāṃ sattvānāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇināṃ
analyzed: bhedana paryavasānāni evam eva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣām sattvānām sarveṣām bhūtānām prāṇinām
translated: end in destruction, end in being broken, in the same way, monks, for all beings, for all creatures, for all that lives,

original: āmaraṇāntaṃ hi jīvita maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: āmaraṇāntam hi jīvita maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya āmaraṇam
translated: life ends in death, ends in dying. There is no birth without death.

analyzed: sugataḥ hi athā parovāca śāstā
translated: Thus spoke the Blessed One, the Well-Gone One, the Fully Enlightened One. Then the Teacher said further:

analyzed: saṃskārāḥ utpāda vyaya dhārmiṇaḥ
translated: Impermanent are all conditioned things; they arise and cease.

analyzed: utpādya hi nirūdhyante teṣām vyapaśamaḥ sukham
translated: Having arisen, they subside; their stilling is bliss.

analyzed: yathā hi kumbhakāreṇa muttikā bhājanam kṛtam
translated: Just as all the vessels made by a potter from clay,

analyzed: sarva bhedana paryantam sattvānām jīvitam tathā
translated: whether baked or unbaked, end in destruction, in the same way, monks, the life of beings ends in death.

analyzed: yathā phalānām pakvānām śaśvat patanataḥ ubhayam
translated: Just as ripe fruits are always in danger of falling,

original: tathā saṃskārajāḥ satvā nityaṃ maraṇato bhayaṃ //
analyzed: tathā saṃskāra jāḥ satvāḥ nityam maraṇataḥ bhayam
translated: in the same way, beings born from conditioned things are always in danger of death.

analyzed: sarva īkṣaya antāḥ nicayāḥ patana antāḥ samucchrayāḥ
translated: All accumulations end in depletion, all rises end in falls,

analyzed: saṃyogāḥ ca viyoga antāḥ jīvitam
translated: all unions end in separation, and all life ends in death.

original: idamavocad bhagavānāttamanāste ca bhikṣavaḥ sā ca parṣadobhagavato bhāṣitamabhyanandan /
analyzed: idam avocat bhagavān ātta manāḥ te ca bhikṣavaḥ sā ca parṣadaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: The Blessed One said this, and those monks were delighted, and they rejoiced in what the Blessed One had said.

analyzed: iti ārya anityatā sūtram samāptam
translated: Thus ends the noble Sutra on Impermanence.
